text: Interviewing for jobs has so far been roughly 1/10th informally giving julia sales pitches to random companies

elements.text: Interviewing for jobs has so far been roughly 1/10th informally giving julia sales pitches to random companies

text: How is it working so far? Were they convinced? :joy:

elements.text: How is it working so far? Were they convinced?

text: one place had actually already been using it here and there, one place had been thinking about using it, but when I explained it they kind of went "hmmmm", I was like "yea if you already have a big code base it might not be worth rewriting it", and the person was like "well actually... if it really is faster and easier to write it might be". And another place was like "cool whatever"

elements.text: one place had actually already been using it here and there, one place had been thinking about using it, but when I explained it they kind of went "hmmmm", I was like "yea if you already have a big code base it might not be worth rewriting it", and the person was like "well actually... if it really is faster and easier to write it might be". And another place was like "cool whatever"

text: it is a challenge until a big company declares they are using the language internally like how python got become ubiquitous in the industry in spite of its shortcomings. i’m happy java was finally kicked out but replacing it with python made my happiness short-lived. when julia takes over, that’s real happiness :joy:. the company that will hire you because they want to change their code-base is a forward thinking company.

elements.text: it is a challenge until a big company declares they are using the language internally like how python got become ubiquitous in the industry in spite of its shortcomings. i’m happy java was finally kicked out but replacing it with python made my happiness short-lived. when julia takes over, that’s real happiness
. the company that will hire you because they want to change their code-base is a forward thinking company.

text: Replacing Java with Python just gets you to have to use yet another language (i.e. C or C++) to make up for the loss of performance :cry:

elements.text: Replacing Java with Python just gets you to have to use yet another language (i.e. C or C++) to make up for the loss of performance

text:
>  the company that will hire you because they want to change their code-base is a forward thinking company.
Zapata Computing qualifies!  They even sponsored JuliaCon 2019 and 2020.

elements.text: the company that will hire you because they want to change their code-base is a forward thinking company.
Zapata Computing qualifies!  They even sponsored JuliaCon 2019 and 2020.

text: (they are also hiring, and are a very fun place to work [even remotely!])

text: Need a Quantum Computing background though :confused: still awesome!

still awesome!

text: Python + Julia + ML skills might be useful :slightly_smiling_face:

text: I certainly didn’t have a QC background

elements.text: I certainly didn’t have a QC background

text: I’m picking stuff up as I go, they do a lot of internal education, with Weekly AMAs and Scientific Paper discussions.

elements.text: I’m picking stuff up as I go, they do a lot of internal education, with Weekly AMAs and Scientific Paper discussions.

text: Might be a little bit off topics, but is quantum computing actually a thing? To my understanding there is still no real hardware (in the sense big enough to do anything more than POCs) so I'm surprised to hear that there are legit companies doing this. But again, I don't really follow what's going on in this space so my assumptions might just be wrong.

elements.text: Might be a little bit off topics, but is quantum computing actually a thing? To my understanding there is still no real hardware (in the sense big enough to do anything more than POCs) so I'm surprised to hear that there are legit companies doing this. But again, I don't really follow what's going on in this space so my assumptions might just be wrong.

text: Lots of hardware, but yes, it’s in early days.  The number of qubits is getting larger every year, as well as the quality and length of time before decoherence. Also, there are a number of competing approaches (just like COVID vaccines :slightly_smiling_face: ), hopefully more than one will pan out in the not so distant future.

elements.text: Lots of hardware, but yes, it’s in early days.  The number of qubits is getting larger every year, as well as the quality and length of time before decoherence. Also, there are a number of competing approaches (just like COVID vaccines
), hopefully more than one will pan out in the not so distant future.

text: Right now, the currently available devices are called NISQ (noisy intermediate scale quantum), and there’s a lot of research into how to develop algorithms that will give an advantage over classical computing even on NISQ devices, as well as how to improve the hardware, to get error corrected qubits, and many many more of them.

elements.text: Right now, the currently available devices are called NISQ (noisy intermediate scale quantum), and there’s a lot of research into how to develop algorithms that will give an advantage over classical computing even on NISQ devices, as well as how to improve the hardware, to get error corrected qubits, and many many more of them.

text: The investment is needed now, IMO, if we want to have this technology progress.

elements.text: The investment is needed now, IMO, if we want to have this technology progress.

text: Wow, thanks for the detailed answer, that's very interesting!

elements.text: Wow, thanks for the detailed answer, that's very interesting!

text: Another point is that the research into algorithms, has actual ended up improving classical computing, as people have come up with “quantum inspired” approaches that beat older classical algorithms.

elements.text: Another point is that the research into algorithms, has actual ended up improving classical computing, as people have come up with “quantum inspired” approaches that beat older classical algorithms.
